Award.AbstractNarration:
It is widely believed that the most fundamental constituents of some of the most common elementary particles are quarks, and their anti-matter counterpart, anti-quarks. By probing the existence and structure of these particles, it is possible to learn about the underlying principles governing quark and anti-quark matter. The work in this project will use data collected at the Belle experiment at the High Energy Accelerator Research Organization (KEK) laboratory in Japan to measure the formation of particles known as mesons that consist of a quark-antiquark pair. By studying these mesons, one can probe fundamental physics processes such as Charge Parity (CP) violation, rare meson decays and the existence of possible exotic particles which could indicate the presence of Dark Matter. This effort has a particular focus on the support of students, thereby contributing to the development of a much-needed high tech workforce.

Belle is built around the interaction region of an asymmetric electron-positron collider, with electrons having the energy of 8 GeV and positrons having the energy of 3.5 GeV, giving 10.58 GeV center-of-mass energy. The main goal of Belle is to detect mesons made of a quark-anti-quark pair, in particular those mesons made of charm quarks (charmonium) and bottom quarks (bottomonium). The Belle Experiment at KEK in Japan has the world's largest data samples recorded at the bottomonium resonances: upsilon (5S), upsilon (2S) and upsilon (1S). The central aim of this project is to perform very precise measurements of details of fragmentation (the break-up of resonant particles such as the upsilon) and hadronization (the process of initial state quarks and gluons decaying into detectable particles like pions and photons) at a center of mass energy of 10 GeV. This will provide tests of Quantum Chromo-Dynamics (QCD), providing detailed information for theoretical Lattice QCD calculations. The decays of the upsilon(1S) resonance to gluons and photons provides a precise measurement of the QCD strong coupling constant.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The Belle analysis work currently comprises three primary efforts, at varying stages of completion:  a) investigation of (unexpected) correlations in charmed baryon production observed in Belle data,  for which the production of /\c, Sigma_c and Sigma_c^* are all enhanced by a factor  of ~3.2 when the recoiling anti-charm quark fragments into an anti-charmed baryon rather than an anti-charmed hadron, b) via analysis of $\Upsilon\to$charm and also $\Upsilon\to\chi_{bJ}\to$charm, studies of coupling of gluons to charmed quarks at $\sqrt{s}\sim$10 GeV, and c) general comparisons of quark vs. gluon fragmentation. Production of charm, and particularly, the mechanisms related to the exotic X and Y charmonium-like particles, has recently received increasing attention as a spectroscopy paralleling `standard' charmonium has emerged within the last decade.

Following several internal presentations, the analysis of charmed baryon correlations is now under review for publication by an internal Belle committee, the second analysis is perhaps 2--3 months away from that threshold, and the latter is in its earliest stages. These measurements are all done in a way that minimizes absolute Monte Carlo dependence, either by internally normalizing or by constructing ratios of ratios. Over the grant period, our group will bring the correlated charmed baryon analysis to conclusion, and then extend the study of the XYZ-exotica to: i) searches for correlated production of charmonium, with both charmonium above D\=D threshold, using partial reconstruction techniques to compensate for low-efficiency, and also ii) investigation of a similar hierarchy of `strange' states (e.g., $e^+e^-\to\phi f_J$ or $e^+e^-\to\phi\eta(')_{(J)}$).

To complement this analysis effort, efforts will be directed towards the commissioning of the Belle-II detector. With collaborators at Lebedev Physical Institute and the Moscow Engineering Physics Institute, under the leadership of Misha Danilov, benchmarks will be developed to ensure that the endcap KLong and Muon detector system (EKLM) built by our sub-group and scheduled for imminent commissioning at Belle-II will perform as expected when the first Belle-II physics data are taken. That EKLM system should give slightly better performance than the current system; very importantly, it is being designed to be robust in the high-luminosity Belle-II environment.

This effort complements analyses of charmonium-like exotica produced in $e^+e^-$; these charmonium-like states do not neatly fit simple q\=q models. Whether these objects are bound hadrons or some other exotica is currently unclear. The role of gluonic coupling to charm in these phenomena will also be investigated.

The outreach aspect of this proposal is realized by extending a full-range of scientific experience to junior researchers. As was the case with CLEO, for which the PI advised eight undergraduates who were the primary analyzers (and authors) for eventual publications, this work similarly easily extends to not only undergraduates, but also high school students, with whom the PI has extensive prior experience. Particle and astroparticle physics has also been incorporated into a local high school class at Lawrence High School, culminating in launch, flight and recovery of a weather balloon carrying a science payload.
